captions.text: Hey guys, ChrisFix here
today I am going to show you how to restore your headlights permanently
so your hazy, oxidized headlights go from
this...
to this
all for around $10 a headlight
you might have seen other methods
that get your headlights clear
like kits you buy in the store
such as the 3M kit
you also might have seen some home remedies
such as using baking soda, toothpaste, vinegar, bug spray
all of these methods are only temporary
and the lenses will just become hazy and oxidized over time
this method I am about to show you is the only permanent method
that doesn't require any maintenance
such as adding wax or adding a sealer every so often
not only do hazy, oxidized headlights look bad
they also decrease the value of your car
so not only will you make your car look better, but
you are going to help increase the value of the car
by fixing your headlights
Here is everything you are going to need to do the job
we have scissors,
a garbage bag,
and tape
this if for taping off your headlight
if you are going to keep your headlight on your car or truck
then you are going to need to tape it off
and use garbage bags to protect the paint
now if you are going to remove the headlight form the vehicle,
then you might just need some tape
we have paper towels
we have sandpaper
we have three types of sandpaper
400 grit
600 grit
and 2000 grit
If your headlights are really yellow, oxidized, and hazy, then you will need to start with 400 grit
but if they are not that bad, you can start with 600 grit
and we are going to be doing a wet sand
so you are going to have to use
a spray bottle or some type of water source
like a hose
and when you finish wet sanding you are going to
clean the lens off with alcohol
before you go to the final step
which is using a clear coat
in this case we are using a
gloss clear
and it is made for plastic
and the big thing is
you want it to be non yellowing and UV resistant
the reason your headlights are all foggy, yellowing, and oxidized
is because the
clear coat on the headlights gets
chipped off over time from rocks hitting it
and just the wear-and-tare of driving
and this clear coat will put a nice barrier
so the plastic cant get yellow and hazy again
most people have scissors, a garbage bag, and paper towels
but if you are going to buy the other stuff
it will cost you around $20
so to make your headlights permanently clear
$10 a headlight, that is not bad
especially since some headlights can cost over $100 each!
I have seen headlights that are over $250 each!
so let me show you the whole process
it's quick
it's easy
and you get awesome results that last the lifetime of your headlight
so the first step I would take is, if you headlights are easily removable
I would remove them
it is a lot easier to do this off the car
unfortunately for the PT Cruiser
it is a pain to get the headlights off
so I will paint them on the car
and just to show you the results you should expect
I was testing out different methods
different sanding grits
different clear coats
and what I am about to show you is how I got my best results
and you can see how clear those are
and this is permanently clear
this method will work on any headlight and get it nice and clear
and you already saw the results
so let me show you how to get those results
these headlights are pretty bad
so I will start with 400 grit sandpaper
if your headlights are not this bad
you can start with 600 grit sandpaper
400 is a little more gritty
600 is more fine
and we will finish it off with a little bit of 2000 grit which is super fine
Because we are keeping the headlights on the vehicle
now is a good time to get your tape out
and we are going to tape around the whole headlight
and leave a nice barrier so we don't scratch the paint
Im using extra wide painters tape
it will help later on when we put the garbage bad around this
because we have to cover the paint on the vehicle
so now we have the whole edge covered
there is no car paint exposed anywhere in here
Now I have my 400 grit sandpaper
and I have water, and I am just going to spray
the headlight with water
Im going to get my sandpaper
and I will spray it with water
make sure both surfaces are soaked
the water acts as a lubricant and prevents deep scratches
into the lens surface, you just want lite scratches
to buff out any oxidation you have
and you want to keep the surface wet
and I am not pressing hard
just go in a circular motion
now as you do this
with the 400 grit
you will notice a milky color
running down
that's all that oxidized, yellowing plastic
that's coming off your headlight
and that's good
you don't want to go crazy with the 400 grit
you don't want to press really hard
you can press harder with the 600 grit
since 400 grit is pretty coarse
on a headlight like this
you also want to get into the groove right here
and then our final sand with the 400 grit
is going to be a horizontal sand
not a swirl anymore
so you can see our scratches are horizontal
they're not swirled anymore
that is the last step that we did
the reason why you want horizontal scratches
is so that when you spray your clear coat
it is less likely to run
and has an edge to grab onto
I don't see anymore of that yellow, oxidization
or haze
I just see the haze
that was created from the sanding
so now we can move to the 600 grit
again get your headlight soaking wet
get your sandpaper soaking wet
and start with the 600 grit
with the 600 grit you can press a little harder
you can see the finer plastic particles
coming off the headlight
that is exactly what you want to see
now that we did a bunch of the swirling motion
with the 600 grit
we are going to switch to the horizontal sanding
and with the final horizontal sanding
with the 600 grit
we have that top layer
of the oxidized headlight
completely removed
and the headlight lens is getting really smooth
so now that we have finished with our 600 grit
we will move up to the 2000 grit
but before we move up to the 2000 grit
we need to clean these off
just going to use some water
and wipe it down with a paper towel
the reason why we do that is because
the 2000 grit is very fine
and any plastic particulate that is still on here
is going to clog up the sandpaper
and you won't get a good final sand
and this final sand is going to help
you get a really good finish on your clear coat
so just spray it down
and get a paper towel and wipe it down
now we are going to get 2000 grit
its going to be a wet sand as well
you don't want to press really hard on this
you just want to skim the surface
you are just going to cut down some of the edge that the
600 grit put on here
and after you do enough of the swirling motion
you can do the horizontal motion
and this will be the final touch
Good, you can see even with the 2000 grit
this looks a lot better
it's still going to be hazy, don't worry
you want it to be hazy
there's still going to be micro scratches on the surface here
the clear coat will fit that in
now you are going to dry it with a paper towel
and after it drys
you will see a nice haze on here
so now we will grab our alcohol
and we will put it on a low lint paper towel
so the lint doesn't get on the cleaned lens
and we will clean the headlight lens off
the alcohol removes any oils
from your hands that may have gotten onto the lens
and it also makes the lens dry quickly
because alcohol evaporates quickly
so as the alcohol drys
cut your garbage bag open
take the garbage bag
cover the front of the car
The whole point of doing this
is because when you spray the clear coat
you don't want the paint to over-spray
onto your hood or any of your paint
or plastic that you have
with the garbage bag all laid out
we will get our tape
and tape up the garbage bag so it is nice and tight

comments.text:
I think I'd definitely hit it with some polishing compound at the last 
stage. But, it looks good overall.﻿
comments.author: PocketDrummer

comments.text:
This works great. The only problem I am having is that more than one coat 
of clear and it starts hazing up again. I did the first headlight and after 
a coat of clear it was looking really good. Then after the second coat it 
looked less stellar. After a third coat it was almost back to its original 
state minus the yellowing. I stripped it back down and started over and got 
the same result. Even after 24 hours it still looked very cloudy. So once 
again I started fresh and decided to stay at one coat and they look 
stellar. It's a Mazda 3 by the way.﻿
comments.author: Jesse Sanders

comments.text:
Awsome vid. ChrisFix.. 
thumbs up﻿
comments.author: Peter R

comments.text:
I am a pro painter (28 yrs. at the Cadillac factory) and I'd like to 
correct one small but IMPORTANT point about shooting paint. Never shoot 
paint like your writing a letter. Always shoot paint from the Bottom Up !! 
Starting at the top and working your way down will give you Sags, Bags, & 
Runs. Starting at the bottom and working your way up WON"T. You heard it 
from a Pro, now pass it on. Otherwise, Great Video!
Thanks Much to ChrisFix !!﻿
comments.author: Dalton Dodd

comments.text:
Nice video Ill share some of my results with you I have had over the years. 
the worst headlights and damage on cars Ive ran into are the  buick 
rendezvous and the 2000-2004 chevy impala. if they let the damage go too 
far the lights are not repairable at all. Also I have been around body 
shops most my entire life . We have always found that 2000 grit is just a 
finishing paper. starting with 400 is necessary on some lights even 320 Ive 
had to use . but I jump from 400 to 800 grit with no issues before clearing 
the lights . any good automotive clear with uv inhibitors will work and 
clear from a can even covers 600 grit scratches easily . I use 800 grit 
just to be sure. I feel that 2000 grit is too far and is actually making it 
more difficult for the clear to adhere to the lights as it kinda buffs them 
out. most of the lights I encounter only need 800 grit and clean and spray. 
trial and error have led me down the path of trying to conserve 
materials...lol

another trick Ive learned is the cleaning and sanding with pure water is 
nice but to speed things up try some of the simple green cleaner . It 
cleans most of the yellow off the lights as you sand and is a way better 
lubricant than the water . it cuts my sanding time in half. just before 
clearing the lights I dont use alcohol as it is prone evaporation  in 
vehicles if stored. I use the spray away glass cleaner in the aerosol  can 
. it is a great way degrease the lights and stores easier . the clears Ive 
tried that I like are upol clear number 1.   scratch wizard headlight 
restore clear . spray max 2k clear its pricey ... but if you have 6 cars to 
do its well worth it . all of these clears have quality and user friendly 
spray tips .  ones ive used with little success is the spedokote uv curing 
clear it likes to fish-eye and orange peal. the duplicolor clear from 
autoparts outlets is the worst it dried almost matte finish. and the 
rustoleam auto clear it came out too fast from the can dried uneven and had 
to water sand to make smooth , so not very user friendly.   hope this 
helps.﻿
comments.author: Stacy Williams

comments.text: Great to know . Now I can do my own lights better than anyone else can.﻿
comments.author: iconaclastor

comments.text:
I've done this and it works great.  Use enamel for the best results 
though.  You can also buff the plastic and forgo the clear coat entirely 
but it's more work.  The clear coat is NOT needed to protect the plastic 
unless the plastic is so severely degraded that you cannot completely sand 
off the porous hydrolized exterior. Headlights are made from UV and solvent 
resistant polycarbonate.﻿

comments.text: +knurlgnar24 Thanks for sharing!

comments.text:
Hey Chris. I love your videos. They are helping me understand a lot about 
what mechanic is doing and how to do some lighter jobs at home. I followed 
this tutorial exactly, even bought the same products. However, my headlight 
is really foggy after using the clear coat. I sprayed three light layers, 
waiting 5-10 minutes in between sprays. I let it sit for 24 hours but it 
was still foggy. I sanded it down again and tried it over. I still ended up 
with the same result, foggy. I used the clear coat gloss, same brand and 
product used in the video. The paint left a layer of fogginess that I'm not 
sure how to get rid of. Any suggestions? ﻿
comments.author: Tundrian12

comments.text:
+ChrisFix No orange peal. It just looks like a blurry glaze of paint on top 
of the headlight. I'm going to check on it tomorrow morning. But it looks 
like it's clear but with a blur. Like, putting a slight-to-moderate blur on 
an image. I sanded with 800 and 2,000 grit today to get the last layer of 
clear coat off, used the iso-propylene alcohol, it fogged up when drying 
(like in the video) then I used clear coat. 3 light layers. Looks blurry. 
Should I use some cleaning kit maybe, after sanding again?
comments.author: Tundrian12

comments.text:
+Tundrian12 Hm, that is strange. Try thicker coats maybe? Is it foggy or is 
there a lot of orange peel?

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
You seen how clear that headlight became with just water before you started 
doing all that work? It buffs real nice with a pad on a bench grinder. Yes 
it needs to be removed from the vehicle. Buff lightly with plastic compound 
do not burn the plastic. Buff horizontally and vertically. All coatings 
will eventually cloud on a cars headlights. Regardless. Too much heating 
and cooling of the surfaces occurs. That is why the plastic clouds to begin 
with. Tail lights don't do that, so it's not the sun so much.
This method in the video may be a better choice for those without the tools 
or knowledge of how to remove the headlight or to use a buffer correctly. 
Good video man.﻿
comments.author: Chaz Z

comments.text: +Chaz Z Thanks!

comments.text:
Hope you answer my question. I just did this.. all was great and the FIRST 
 clear gloss coat was best after the first layer - it was super clear and 
super new looking -.. once I began doing the second and third  layer.. this 
is where I lost the clarity -it has yet to be clear - orange peel is what 
 I see.. its been a few hours.. but you say within 24 hours it should 
become glass clear.. I have a hard time believing that..but if it doesn't 
 I guess I restart and just do a one pass gloss layer. How many coats can 
you do.I ll let you know how it goes within the 24 hours.﻿
comments.author: BX0207

comments.text:
+ChrisFix 
Buffed with medium compund and after wet sand with 2000.. compound took 
away a big part of orange peel. went down to a polish and then a wax.. very 
clean.. but still not 100% clear.. Like I said.. the first coat gave the 
utmost clear finish... the second and third coats gave it a lot fo orange 
peel and not clear at all..
comments.author: BX0207

comments.text:
+ChrisFix i sprayed very evenly and not too close
.but i ll let you know. Like i said the first coat looked amazing..the 
following ones caused the o.p. i think coats should maybe be longer hours 
apart..i will do the 2000 wet sand before starting over...thanks for 
answering Chris
comments.author: BX0207

comments.text:
+BX0207 Let me know how it looks after 24hrs. Your coats might not have 
been even which created a good amount of orange peel. If that is the case 
you can always wet sand with 2000 grit so the orange peel is even and then 
buff the lens with compound. Or you can start over with 400 grit! Keep me 
posted!

+ChrisFix yea thanks I re-sanded and before I sprayed the clearcoat I 
buffed it with a rubbing and polishing compound they came out nice :)
comments.author: MMYoShii

comments.text:
+MMYoShii Hm, was it humid? Did you use thick or thin layers? You can 
always start over by using 400 grit sandpaper but before you do that try 
using 2000 grit sandpaper and even out the clear coat. Then get a compound 
and buff the lenses good. That should clear them up. Then add a layer of 
wax. Let me know!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: How much pressure do I put when I wet sand before applying wax?﻿
comments.author: Geon Kim

comments.text:
+Geon Kim You should press the same hardness as when you sanded before. You 
will sand it until it is uniform and then you will have to use a compound 
to buff the lenses. After that, you can add some wax. The key is to sand it 
even with the 2000 grit and then buff it really good so it is clear and 
smooth with the compound.

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
After 24 hours, I kind of messed up my car's left headlight's gloss clear 
coat... There are some uneven layers and run... 
Just by wet sanding it with 2000 grit sandpaper and applying wax, will the 
uneven layer and run be gone?﻿
comments.author: Geon Kim

comments.text:
+Geon Kim Spray it really light and do layers. The layers can be done one 
right after the other. Start from the bottom and move up, when you get to 
the top, go back down to the bottom and move up again. Do this until you 
think you might get some runs. It is all about practice. Maybe try spraying 
something else to get an idea of how much paint will cause a run.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix When I spray the gloss clear, what are some tips to prevent runs? 
My headlight is curvy and so wide... (06 Hyundai azera).
comments.author: Geon Kim

comments.text:
When I spray the gloss clear, what are some tips to prevent runs? My 
headlight is curvy and so wide... (06 Hyundai azera).
comments.author: Geon Kim

comments.text:
+Geon Kim Unfortunately, for runs, you might need to start all over again. 
You can try this first though... Try sanding the spots that did not come 
out good with 2000 grit so they are even with the rest of the light. Then 
use a rubbing compound and a buffer to buff the lens smooth. If not, start 
all over with 400 grit.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hey Chris. After waiting 24 hours, Did you wet sand before applying the wax 
?﻿
comments.author: Geon Kim

comments.text:
+Geon Kim Unfortunately, for runs, you might need to start all over again. 
You can try this first though... Try sanding the spots that did not come 
out good with 2000 grit so they are even with the rest of the light. Then 
use a rubbing compound and a buffer to buff the lens smooth. If not, start 
all over with 400 grit.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix Should I wet sand with 2000 grit sandpaper if there is some kind 
of run of my car's one side of headlight clear coat? Accidentally, I put 
the gloss clear too much on my left side headlight... So it looks like 
"run." Will the 2000 grit wet sand remove the run and apply wax?
comments.author: Geon Kim

comments.text:
+Geon Kim I did not wet sand because the clear coat came out so good. If 
you have a lot of orange peel, you can wet sand with 2000 grit then buff 
with compound, then wax.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+vickh42 Awesome! If you followed the steps I showed, it will last years. 
Mine has lasted years and it still looks new!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hey Chris, I did this on my 04 Lancer and wow it looks great. Except, I 
think I oversprayed too much clear coat and theres seems to be some 
smudges. Is there anything I can do to fix it now or do I have to do it all 
over again?﻿
comments.author: Chris Vela

comments.text:
+Chris Vela Unfortunately, for runs, you will need to start all over again. 
You might try this... Try sanding the spots that did not come out good with 
2000 grit so they are even with the rest of the light. Then use a rubbing 
compound and a buffer to buff the lens smooth. If not, start all over with 
400 grit.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: cool﻿
comments.author: metalbunnycom

comments.text: Hey did this but i got orange peel . How can i get rid of it?﻿
comments.author: William Taboada

comments.text:
+William Taboada Sand the orange peel down with 1000 or 2000 grit until it 
is uniformly hazy and then take a compound and buff it really good until it 
is nice and clear!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
HEY CHRIS, I FOLLOWED ALL OF THE STEPS AND THE HEADLIGHTS CAME OUT CRAZEE. 
THE ONLY SLIGHT ISSUE IS THAT WHEN THE LIGHT IS ON, THERES A HAZED HALO 
WHERE THE LIGHT SHINES THROUGH. ANY IDEAS?...THANX RAUL﻿
comments.author: Raul Valles (54Capt)

comments.text:
I used the 400 grit, 800 grit, then the 2000 grit for the last part of the 
sanding process. Maybe going a little higher on the grit, like 3000 might 
do it too. I was also experimenting on using a metal polishing oil instead 
of the clear coat and to tell you the truth, it actually came out better 
then the clear coat but dont know how long its gonna last. I did that 
process on a 1998 Ford Taurus. I took some pics. I'll let you know how long 
it lasts. really dig your videos. Thanx for the info
comments.author: Raul Valles (54Capt)

comments.text:
+Raul Valles Awesome man! The halo might be from the orange peel on the 
lens. If you want, try sanding with a 2000 grit wet sand so the surfaces is 
evenly scuffed up. Then get some compound and buff it in really good until 
the lens is crystal clear. If it isnt that bad, I would leave it since it 
sounds like you did a good job!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
My wife has a PT Cruiser and she let one of the local "car-heads" (read: I 
can turn a wrench so I know stuff...) do a store-bought headlight restore 
on her car.  Within weeks it was already yellowing BAD!  My brother, and 
actually-educated car guy said that after this person used his thing that 
we can't actually fix her headlights and that we'd have to buy them.  I was 
about to do that until I found this video.  So now I'm curious: Should I 
even attempt this on hers?  I've driven her car recently and the headlights 
barely seem to show up.﻿
comments.author: Lone Wulf

comments.text:
+Lone Wulf Do it! You will be happily surprised at how good it comes out! 
If you dont like it, you can always sand it off. Take some before and after 
pics!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: I meant the clear coat not silicon ...﻿
comments.author: Fernando Vera

comments.text:
+Fernando Vera Gotcah. Reply to your original comment so all of the info is 
in one place.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: could use 3000 paper after 2000.﻿
comments.author: Pitur

comments.text:
+Pitur You do not want to buff the lens smooth. You want to have scratches 
and follow the 400-600-2000 exactly like in this video. The 600 grit puts 
deep enough scratches into the surface of the lens while the 2000 light 
sand, cuts any surface roughness off. This allows for the clear coat to 
adhere properly so it wont peel in a year. If you make it smooth, the clear 
coat wont grab onto anything and it will peel. You can also have a problem 
with the paint running.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text: thanks I find it, good video.﻿
comments.author: jhovani herrera

comments.text: +jhovani herrera Glad you liked the video!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:

use clearcoat, I'd suggest color sanding and buffing.﻿

comments.text: +Robert Gantry Thanks for the feedback Robert.

comments.text:
I learned a little trick from a friend that is a detailer.  Same process 
but if you want to be even more of a perfectionist after the 2000 Grit take 
a polishing compound to it as well.  Adds a little more expense but the 
results are really worth it. Keep up the good videos.  He also emphasized 
the UV protection after coat but I can't remember the kind he swore by.﻿
comments.author: NerdRage

comments.text:
I think the paint running issue is why he probably had a UV coating that he 
swore by. You know those car guys getting set in their ways.  He did the 
lenses in my Mustang I was going to give it a go on my Cougar. I can 
compare them side by side but I don't think that would be fair.  He is a 
pro I am an amateur.
comments.author: NerdRage

comments.text:
+NerdRage Thanks for sharing but, you do not want to buff the lens smooth. 
You want to have scratches and follow the 400-600-2000 exactly like in this 
video. The 600 grit puts deep enough scratches into the surface of the lens 
while the 2000 light sand, cuts any surface roughness off. This allows for 
the clear coat to adhere properly so it wont peel in a year. If you make it 
smooth, the clear coat wont grab onto anything and it will peel. You can 
also have a problem with the paint running.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I have been doing a lot of research on restoring headlights and seen the 
sealant methods as well, have you seen a durability test for clearcoat vs 
sealant? How are your lights holding up? And is your car outside most the 
day/in the sun? Thanks for the vid!﻿
comments.author: Jordan Isbell

comments.text:
+Jordan Isbell This is the best method I could come up with. It has lasted 
over a year and still looks brand new! The car is outside all day, every 
day. This winter was bad too! The headlights were frozen solid multiple 
times and it still looks great. I was impressed!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hi Chris, thank you for the helpful vid.  I followed your instructions 
today, and for the most part, I am very happy with the results.  One 
headlight though, is still a bit blotchy-looking from the spray paint (I 
did 3 coats).  I wondered if you could tell me if another coat would clear 
it up more, or if doing the wet sand with the 2000 grit would help. 
 Thanks!﻿

Thanks Chris.  I actually was able to get most of the blotchy orange-peel 
type stuff off with a final sand using the 2000 grit paper.  Will try to 
post some before/after pics.  Thanks again!

+586101 No problem! Glad the video was helpful! You can try another coat 
and if it doesnt work, sand it down with 400 grit and start over.
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Super helpful video! My headlights have gone to shit in the last 5 years of 
owning the car and I'm planning to do this over the summer. Thanks for 
showing the type of clear coat as well, that was something I was having a 
hard time finding online or with other tutorials. Someone told me to use 
Klean Strip Bulldog Adhesive first, is that really necessary or not because 
Rust Oleum bonds to plastic?﻿
comments.author: fearlesslove7

comments.text:
+fearlesslove7 I am glad the video was helpful! Do exactly what you saw in 
the video and it will last a long time and come out great!
comments.author: ChrisFix

Hello Chris, could you please tell me where did you found the clear coat

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Hey Chris, thanks for this. A year ago, I used a "headlight restore" kit 
that, while it worked great initially, of course left the lens exposed to 
further damage. Just followed your ideas here, actually have my headlights 
curing in a makeshift "oven" of a rubbermaid tote, and a space heater (low 
heat, plenty of space, been running for a few days). Massive improvement, 
but I forgot to get before video. Have some "in progress" video, that I'll 
get up after I wax and reinstall the lights.

Thanks for the ideas, and the help!﻿
comments.author: Goldmarble

comments.text: +Goldmarble Awesome! I cannot wait to see the pictures!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:

restoration kits with the main difference being the clear coat. Nice choice 
of wax btw, Collinite 476s , the most durable wax out. ﻿

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
+ChrisFix One question:

I watched your other video about using the bug spray to clean the lights 
and how clear it got them temporarily.

So... if I used the bug spray, then cleaned the light well immediately 
after, then applied the clear coat paint and wax to the light, could that 
be a permanent fix also? I would imagine so since the primary intent is to 
remove the oxidation first, which the bug spray does... right?﻿
comments.author: Jo_Gets_His

comments.text:
+Jo_Gets_His you do not want the lens to be smooth and the bug spray will 
cause the clear coat to bubble if you didnt get all of it off. You want to 
have scratches and follow the 400-600-2000 exactly like in this video. The 
600 grit puts deep enough scratches into the surface of the lens while the 
2000 light sand, cuts any surface roughness off. This allows for the clear 
coat to adhere properly so it wont peel in a year. If you make it smooth, 
the clear coat wont grab onto anything and it will peel. You can also have 
a problem with the paint running.

comments.text:
This is bullshit Im a professional car painter and im doing hedlights 
polishing aswell.Don't use clear lack cose they are all gonna go yelow 
after some time.Use the same method as described in the process and then do 
the 3 stage polishing with the 3m pastes.If you don't have a polishing 
machine do it by hand nice and slowly.Dont spraypaint them with clear cos 
it corodates the plexiglas.and after that hedlights are fuckt up.﻿
comments.author: Lucijan Cavallin

well. Head lights are not Plexiglas either.

comments.text:
Hey Chris, It did not work out well for my 3 series. I used 600 and 2000 
grit sand paper and the same clear coat spray as yourself. The first coat 
on the left headlight made it look amazing and as I added more coats 
(light) after every 10 mins it started to look hazy. I thought i'll let it 
dry but after 14 hours it looked the same. This morning i lightly sanded 
the headlight and used light compound and car wax but not much difference. 
After all this I used baby oil and they look amazing!!! But I know the oil 
trick is only temporary. Please advise if I missed on anything. (I did'nt 
use 400 as my headlight were not in a bad condition to start with)﻿

I'd recommend using wax instead of clear coat....
Not auto body wax, hot molten paraffin wax. Trust me, it lasts just as 
long, no orange peel, no flaking.﻿

Don't listen to the last part he says about the optional resending with 
2000 or 3000 grit sand paper after the clear coat!!! It will ruin the whole 
thing and it will create a haze looking! What a poor advise! Just apply wax 
after clear coats. I am very upset about that because he obviously has not 
done it before and went ahead and made a terrible optional advice which he 
didn't show. I had to redo the whole thing over again!﻿
